title: 106_hr2309
content: The Act may be cited as the "Independent Medical Review Act of 1999" and includes special rules for group health plans. Section 503 of ERISA is amended to include special rules for group health plans, such as notification of appeal rights to utilization review agents and independent review organizations. The procedures for appealing an adverse determination to an independent review organization include notification to a participant with a life-threatening condition of their right to immediate review and fair determination of medical necessity without regard to the plan's definition. Participants can appeal a denial of benefits to a utilization review agent with reasonable procedures in place. The appeal process for adverse determinations allows the beneficiary, participant, or their representative to appeal orally or in writing. The utilization review agent must acknowledge receipt of the appeal within 5 days and provide a list of required documents. If the appeal is denied, a physician will make the final decision, unless the healthcare provider provides a written justification for a specialty provider within 10 days. The appeal process for adverse determinations includes a method for expedited appeals for emergency care denials and life-threatening conditions. A health care provider of the same specialty as the medical condition under review must complete the specialty review within 15 working days. The appeal process for adverse determinations includes a provision for expedited appeals based on medical or dental urgency, with a response letter detailing the resolution of the appeal. Written notification of the appeal determination must be provided within 30 days of receiving the appeal. Independent review of adverse determinations is also available. The appeal process for adverse determinations includes expedited appeals for medical or dental urgency, with a response letter detailing the resolution. If an appeal is denied by a utilization review agent, independent review by an independent review organization can be sought, ensuring timely responses, confidentiality of medical records, and independence of healthcare providers making determinations. The utilization review agent must provide relevant medical records and documents to the independent review organization within 3 business days of receiving a request for review of an adverse determination. The utilization review agent must provide medical records and documents to the independent review organization within 3 business days. The independent review organization must make its determination within 15 days. The participant or beneficiary must receive written notification of the clinical basis for the denial of the appeal. The independent review organization must make a determination within a specified timeframe, depending on whether it is a regular or life-threatening condition. The independent review organization must make a determination within a specified timeframe, either upon receiving necessary information or by the 8th day after receiving the request. To be certified as an independent review organization, an organization must submit an annual application to the Secretary. The organization applying for certification as an independent review organization must provide detailed information including the names of stockholders owning more than 5%, affiliated corporations, bond holders exceeding $100,000, biographical sketches of directors and executives, and any relationships with health insurance providers or health maintenance organizations. The organization seeking certification as an independent review organization must provide information on their anticipated revenue sources, the expertise of their review professionals, and the procedures used for making determinations. The independent review organization must follow specific procedures for making review determinations, and their decisions are final and binding on the plan unless vacated or modified by a court. The organization must be independent and not affiliated with payors or their associations. The independent review organization must be independent and not affiliated with payors or their associations. It is not liable for damages arising from its determinations.
